ud1.4:1.2: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
ud1.4:1.3: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
ud1.4:1.4: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion.
ud1.4:2.1: Then a certain brahmin of the whiny sort went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
ud1.4:2.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side,
ud1.4:2.4: “Master Gotama, how do you define a brahmin? And what are the things that make one a brahmin?”
ud1.4:3.1: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud1.4:4.1: “A brahmin who has barred out bad qualities,
ud1.4:4.3: a complete knowledge master who has completed the spiritual journey—
ud1.4:4.4: may rightly proclaim the brahmin doctrine,
ud1.4:4.5: free of pride about anything in the world.”
